segments.text: Okay, today is June 9th, 1981.
This is our second interview with General Kidwell.
And last time we finished, well, we just basically covered the end of the war.
We talked about General Clark a little bit.
We got to May 1945.
And you were in Austria.
And there are a couple of questions I want to ask.
All right.
When you were with the conference between the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, and France, attempting to exactly what were you attempting to do?
I guess I should start.
What were we attempting to do?
Yeah, you said that you were trying to set up the utilities.
You were the chief public works and utility officer.
Right.
Our job or our responsibility was to
to reestablish electric energy in Austria.
Austria is a country that lives with electric power, both hydroelectric and coal-fired steam generation.
And none of the occupying forces or conquering forces
knew what they had.
They just knew to turn the lights on and switch on and nothing happened.
And of course in combat, wires get shot down, power stations get bombed, railroad lines get bombed, and power lines inherently follow railroad lines because it's the most easily constructed area.
And so

The governing powers, meaning the quadripartite level of General Mark Clark for the American representative and an English general, a French general, and a Russian general, set about going to govern these occupied, and relatively speaking, Russia
Each nation had about a fourth of it.
Russia got the biggest fourth, but our job is, we were appointed, I was appointed as the public utility officer representing the American forces.
It was a English brigadier, French brigadier, and a Russian major general that was masquerading as a major.
Why, I don't know.
That's how curious.
Well, it was their method of subterfuge.
He was an artilleryman, and that gave me the entree to breaking him down and knowing a whole lot about him.
And he was a British soldier.
What was his name?
Correct Cole.
Correct Cole.
How do you spell that?
I pronounce it K-R-E-C-K-O, but that may not be the pronunciation.
I mean the spelling, but that's the way you pronounce it correctly.
The American Army got the identification and intelligence on him through some of my endeavors, and that set him on the trail of proving out who he was and why he was masquerading as a major.
I'll never know, but that is it.
What kind of person was he?
He was a very likable person.
He always had his, I call it, his political commissar with him.
He would never make a statement without huddling with his fellow.
I forget his name, but he was a civilian.
But he was a politician, or the communist representative versus the military representative.
And they were inseparable.
They went hand in glove, and both of them would yak at the interpreter.
And an interpreter would, I guess, blend what they were saying and come in and tell me what it was or tell the group what it was.
Why do you say he was likable?
He was likable.
He was pleasant.
If it was a cat and mouse or a poker game with him, he never knew anything.
And of course, I tried to inform myself on what I wanted to know before I ever got there.
And he would lie to you just looking you right in the face.
He caught hands down with his hand in the cookie jar, but he didn't swear at it.
No, he was sitting over here reading the Bible or something.
He was a funny fellow, but he was likable.
I mean, he was pleasant to talk with.
And as an artilleryman, we had a lot to talk about.
Their philosophy on artillery is very different from ours.
I explained yesterday where they fire area fire versus pinpoint fire that the American Army
They don't have the capabilities.
They didn't at that time, let's say it that way.
Our job, we had a meeting and discussed what we were going to do and how we were going to do it.
And most people all looked to the American Army to be the leader.
Even the Russians?
The Russians, the French, and the English.
Purely and simply because they were over there as conquerors and to take whatever they could get.
where the American army was over there to restore peace and to set the economy back up and get it working and then turn the government back to the Austrians.
Of course, it had been controlled by the Nazis and the American approach was to turn it over back to the Austrians.
So, we decided that before we could,
tell our superiors anything about the the condition of the power plants and the power line and all we had inventory of them.
Yeah.
Weren't there any Austrians around to help?
Any Austrians?
Well this is the point I'm leading up to.
The Russians and the American, I mean the English and the French
look to the American Army to do this.
Set the power plants up, get our soldiers in there, our technicians, and our equipment, and get the thing running so they could turn the light on and something would happen.
Even in the Russian zone?
In the Russian zone, yes.
They wanted our help.
They were only interested in, for instance, the Russians were interested in dismantling the plants and hauling them back to Russia.
And I'll tell you a story about that later.
I'll get into the details of the thing.
The English were interested in setting Tito up down in Yugoslavia.
And they wanted to take all the Jews' power, excess power that they had in their area, transmit it to Yugoslavia to set them up.
Mm-hmm.

And the French, they were just a bunch of leeches, meaning they were interested in pillaging and taking back to France, because the Germans had done them that way, and as far as they were concerned, the Austrians were Germans.
Yeah.
So, our first... What about the British?
Well, the British were interested in hauling and taking, transmitting their power, excess power, or some of their power, and getting the excess from the American area, and piping it down to
Yugoslavia to set Tito up.
The British?
The British, yes.
I thought you said the Russians wanted to set Tito up.
No, no, the British.
The Russians want to haul the stuff back to Russia.
Oh, okay, okay, okay.
I was a little confused there.
The British were interested in setting Tito up down in Yugoslavia for some reason or another.
Mr. Churchill was very pro-Tito in Yugoslavia.
He was trying to set that nation up and
That was the directive and of course that's our approach to it.
So the first thing we had to do was find out what power plants were in operation.
And of course I was able to secure a list of the power plants in Vienna through captured documents and through normal relations with the power industry there, which was centralized in Vienna.

So we took out and it fell on my shoulders to furnish the transportation and the food and all this kind of business because we were able to and I did it to get my job done rather than say, well, I'll take you in the American zone and then there's no telling what'll happen in the Russian zone or the French zone or the Miami zone, the English zone.
So I furnished transportation and the fuel and the driver and we made a tour of all the power plants in all of Australia and inventorying them.

I said the other three nations were interested in the Americans doing the restoration and I took the attitude that it wasn't an American job that we were certainly going to do in our sector, no question about that.
if we had to, but the approach that I took was that we should get the Austrians who worked in that power plant, who were superintendents of that power plant, to do the restoration.
He knew what power lines were down and what weren't.
He knew which switch to pull to energize one south or one east or one west, and certainly we didn't.
It would have taken us years to get in there and actually rebuild the thing as far as we were concerned.

So I went to General Saltman, who was my superior, and told him what I'd realized and my approach to it, and of course he checked it out with General Clark as a directive, and that's what we decided to do.
That we would...
get the Austrians to restore their plant.
Get the Austrians to restring the lines.
And if need be, we could furnish the wire.
Yeah, we could give them the supplies.
We could give them the supplies if need be.
But first, we were going to make them, with their own capabilities, do it.
How did Austrians respond to this idea?
Yes, they very much liked it because that meant to us we put them back on the payroll and got them to helping themselves.
And that was our big job is to get them to helping themselves to restore their own industry.
So we took a tour of all Austria and that was really a fantastic experience because it's the most gorgeous country in the world.
and a lot of good Austrians.
They were all eager to get about their chores when I laid it out to them with the concurrence of these other people and they got about doing it.
You had no problems under the Austrians?
No problems.
They were very cooperative.
Sometimes we had to furnish them with
with diesel fuel to run their trucks, for instance.
And that was a small price to pay.
Sometimes we furnished them with some wire for a critical lap or loop or something around some bad areas or something like that.
We'd furnish them wire, and then they'd furnish the poles and the manpower.
It was the manpower that I was fighting because I didn't want to take as much American soldiers and rebuild a thing for them.

As far as I was concerned, the American soldiers had done his job, and he was just over staying trained, and that was our big chore of keeping him at a high point of training so that if something erupted, well, we were capable of going back to combat.
And you never knew.
Were there fears that?
Well, there might be a pocket of German resistance someplace.
No, that was close.
Or was Japan a worry?
Well, of course, VJ Day had already passed.
Right, OK.
So frankly, the fear was of the Russians.
No question about it, in my mind.
Did you talk about this with your colleagues?
I'm sorry?
Did you talk about this?
Not in this group.
All we talked about was the weather and hunting and power transmission and generations.
But certainly I got it through our G2 information on what our preparations were for.
But we were trying to defensively think and yet
Offensively, we go about our job of restoring power.
And all the time in the back of your mind, you don't trust them.
You don't trust any of them.
I didn't trust any of them.
Why is that?
Because you dealt with them?
Because I dealt with them and learned that you couldn't trust them.
For instance, back in combat now, you can talk about trusting them.
And this is an English colonel.
We were up in repelling Germany.
It's not too far from Aachen.
We'd had some tremendous firefights.
Some of the worst fighting in the whole door-to-door fighting for doughboys.
And I had my headquarters in a monastery at

took us in, and it was a dry place, a warm place, or at least it wasn't cold, let's set it that way, it wasn't warm, but it was probably 50, 55, something like that in there, and they kept it livable, but nothing else.
And I was out on about my chores one day, and I came back, and I saw an English Jeep right in front of my gate.
And I looked in there, and here's a map board, you know what a map board is,
about a square with a map of the area on it, and he's got his locations pointed around.
And there's my battalion area, and my battalion headquarters marked on the map board, in an unguarded jeep.
And this colonel had taken his belt off with his pistol and laid it on top of his map board, knocked on the door, and our guards let him in, and he was in there waiting for me to come have lunch.
Obviously, he just came by to say hello.
But he timed it so he'd be there at lunchtime, because they loved to come and eat with us.
We had good food, and they didn't.
So that's the answer there.

But the point I'm making is that you can't trust them, because if he handles top secret data that way, and certainly that's top secret to me and top secret to the American Army, my exact coordinates on the thing, in combat, the Germans may be five miles from there, four miles, something like that.
You don't trust them.
You can't trust them.
So I carried that philosophy all the way through until I got home.
So the only ones you trusted then were not the British or the Russians, but only the Americans.
Only the Americans.
An American tells you something, well, that's gospel.
But you couldn't trust the other nationals.
He completely exposed my position.
Sure.
He laid his gun on top of it and walked off and left it.
Any German kid could come along, picked up both of them, and gone.
And that's transmitted back immediately to the German army.
And then they blow a kid with that asshole.
And that's something that you don't do.
Do you think that the English then were as distrustful as the Russians?
Or do you think there was a degree?
Well, it's a degree and it's maybe a different sense of distrust, but it boiled down to where you don't trust them.
I wouldn't give them any confidential information, any secret information.
I just wouldn't do it because I didn't know where it was going.
Do you think this is the general feeling among the American officers?
Well it was in my area, let's just say it that way.
Was there a question of superiority or inferiority?
I mean did you think that you were a superior officer or did you think your American troops were better than English or could you comment on that?
Well of course I always had the attitude that the American officer was far superior to any of the others.
Just down the line from second lieutenant all the way up to the
General Eisenhower, there's no question in my mind about that.
On the other hand, up there they had their methods of handling this intelligence business and out in field we had ours and on down to my battalion.
Now this is back when we were still in combat, of course.
But that fear of
The unknown is something that you don't get over once you've been shot at.
Back in combat again, my people knocked down a Messerschmitt that had been by.
We saw him when he went by us, and where he went I don't know, but 10 or 15 minutes away he came back by.
and started unloading his guns on us.
We say clearing the board, it's getting rid of his ammunition.
And they knocked him down.
And our people got over to him and first thing he do is cut his signals off here which gives his rank and his organization and all that stuff for intelligence.
And they picked up his clipboard, again his map board.
And there's my battalion's coordinates on there, and he had it plotted on his boards.
Now how he got it, I don't know.
But one of these old men that was left in this little town, or some kid, got the word back through their gate, Grapevine, and he knew exactly where we were.
Well, all this is indelibly impressed and printed on your memory.
Sure.
And you can't take that thing lightly.
No, no.
So he was probably moving in for the kill?
He was attempting to bomb you then?
Well, he had a bomb mission, and he went and unloaded his bomb, but he came back and unloaded his machine guns on us, and our people got him.
But that didn't eradicate my battalion coordinates off his clipboard.
Sure, yeah.
So what'd you do, move immediately?
No, no.
We were cautious about the thing, but we moved in a day or two.
But you can't move immediately.
You've just got to be super cautious and get ready for them.
Because there are people close to you on the right, close to you on the left, and you can't go backwards.
And you can't go forwards.
So you're hemmed in a goose egg that we operate in.
We moved gun positions, sure.
maybe two, three hundred yards, so they couldn't fire with their long-range artillery or with these flea bombs.
But you can't move.
I mean, to get out of country, that's what I should say.
So I just didn't trust any of those people that we were working with, and I think my fears were justifiable.
You know, often the British, I've read

quite a bit about the British military and they felt that they'd been in the war for two years before we even got in the war and that they had won battles before we joined the war effort and that they were rather upset by the fact that Americans now came in and were running the crusade.
Did you ever get some negative feelings from British officers about this?
The answer is no.
I think that's more of a historian's fabrication than anything else.
It didn't reflect down in our area.
Now the British had been occupying countries for several hundred years.
And they knew how to occupy them.
For instance, I was the northmost, my battalion was the northmost American outfit in the Ninth Army.
and the second British Army was right on our border, which means a lot of times we'd get into their area and a lot of times they'd get into our area and you can't help it.
But conflict like that, I mean conflict meaning cross boundaries.
One day we got word the night before that we were gonna move out and we were really relieved by a British artillery outfit.
which meant that Army or Corps or somebody had swapped a boundary, you know, and they would come in and take our area, and maybe we were going to move south a little bit or something.
I don't remember.
But this Lieutenant Colonel, battalion commander, came in my headquarters about 9.30, 10 o'clock in the morning.
He was British, no?
British.
came in to take over the area.
And I said, hell, I ain't going nowhere.
I'm happy right here.
Nothing happening, you know.
All's quiet, and all we're doing is firing a little harassment fire, and no problems.
We're not going anywhere.
And he said, oh, yeah, you're going here, and I'm supposed to take over the area.
And I said, oh, shit.
I'm not going anywhere.
I don't know anything about it.
And we talked about some cities that he and I had both been in, you know.
We'd passed over there, you know.
Oh, it was 11, 30, something like this time we got down to getting ready for lunch, and I asked him if he'd like to stay for lunch with us.
And he said he would.
But he was anxious to get his people, meaning his equipment and all, coming in and taking over our area.
And I said, I ain't going nowhere.
I don't have any orders to go anywhere.
Did you call back to headquarters then?
Did I call back to headquarters?
Well, I knew I was going to move, but I knew I wasn't going to move until about 4.30.
I think it's 4.30 that afternoon.
And I wouldn't give him the satisfaction of letting him know about it.
Why not?
Well, I didn't know.
I was still responsible for fire if the soldiers in front of us had needed it, till 430.
And I couldn't be getting up and moving out and letting him go up.
Then my core artillery officer called for a certain fire.
And I said, hell, General, I can't give it to you.
I'm moving.
This is, line me up if you want me to move out early.
I just wouldn't give him any satisfaction at all, because I had that responsibility.
He had lunch with us.
And after lunch, I got up and walked around.
And of course, he could see our people had the information to get ready to leave at 430.
And he could see the preparations.
He knew something was cooking.
But I would never admit it to him.
But walked out in his, by that time, he had his.
It's battalion commander's party there.
Now that battalion commander's party is his staff, his wire section, and all that kind of business.
And there were two Studebaker trucks.
I'd never seen a Studebaker truck, a six by six, you know, with a bow top and a canvas on it and all buttoned down, battened down like it, they had something in there really secret.
And I admired them and I asked him how they ran and where he got them and this kind of business.
And of course it's all a land lease business.
But I picked up the tarp and looked in there and my God, completely full of Budweiser canned beer.
Two of them.
I had never seen any Budweiser canned beer in Europe.
And that was his ration, or he was responsible for issuing it, or something.
I never did find out what that was.
But there again, a light lit up in my brain.
And I got to thinking that I would somehow get some of that beer.
I got to negotiating in my own mind.
And about 3 o'clock in the afternoon,
He could see us starting to get our headquarters ready to move out.
There's no question about it, he knew it.
And I said, well, I just got word, of course I got away from him and came back and I just got a message that we were gonna move out.
We got to start picking up a wire and all.
Our wire, we must have had a hundred miles of wire strung out.
An artillery outfit gets awfully strung out and that's quite a chore.
And he asked me twice, how about leaving that wire intact so he wouldn't have to string it?
And I just told him, no way.
Now, what kind of wire is this?
This is telephone wire.
I see.
So you can talk to all the units.
Well, I wouldn't talk to all the units, theoretically in secret, rather than on the radio.
See, the radio exposes you to where you are.
Sure, the airway, sure.
And it's wide open for intelligence, where wire theoretically isn't.
They can tap wire just...
by putting a clip on it, and that's that.
But we run it enough to know if it's being done.
I said, we run it, meaning have a walker walk in the lines, keep them in service, and be sure nobody's tampering with them.
And I said, no way.
Of course, that gave me the idea of it was getting old, and we had done a lot of maintenance on it, meaning tying it, patching it, and this kind of thing.
And it was leaking, so that gave me the idea of just battle losing the wire.
And about 3.30, I guess, I made a deal with this old boy that we'd leave our wire intact for enough beer to give every one of my people a can of beer.
And he didn't go for that very well.
But then again, he got to thinking about it.
And that's what we did.
We traded that wire intact, in place.
for a can of beer for every one of my people, 400 and some odd cans of beer.
Well, those things happen.
The end of the story is... Well, why didn't you have any Budweiser over there?
I don't understand that.
I don't know, I don't know.
Didn't you have any American canned beer?
They had American beer, yes, but there again, I hadn't seen any Budweiser.
And we rarely got it.
because we were a Army battalion.
That thing comes in the Army, goes to Corps, down to divisions.
And see, we weren't a part of any division.
We were separate troops, an Army battalion.
And we just didn't get it.
I mean, the division's supposed to service us.
We're taxed to them for rations and supplies, meaning rations to food and ammunition, gasoline, that kind of business.
But we take orders for firing from somebody else.
And that was one of the deficient points of being a separate battalion.
You were kind of like a bastard at a family reunion.
They wanted you when they needed your fire, but they didn't want to service your outfit.
Anyway, I introduced this English commander to, we had lunch, and of course we used our field kitchens and all.
It was what you would expect in combat.
It wasn't a mess line for the officer's mess, but it was, we used plates and knives and forks, but we didn't have tablecloths, we didn't have napkins, we were in the field.
But this, I introduced this... Did you have hot food done?
Oh, you bet.
For the men and for the officers?
Oh, you bet.
Yes, sir.
That's one thing that I was adamant about.
We didn't serve food unless it was hot, and we took it to the men.
They didn't have to walk a half mile, a mile to get a meal.
We took it to the men.
They drove it out on a jeep?
Drove it out on a jeep or in a command car, whatever they had available, you know.
Bet you they liked that.
Well, sure.
Well, you had to take care of them.
But I introduced this British colonel, this commander, to...
the German that owned this house we were in.
And he talked to him in German.
He could talk German.
And he told him he wanted to get the silver out on the table for supper.
He wanted tablecloths and napkins.
He wanted the rugs put back on the floor.
He wanted the finest china that they had and all.
And they got it.
I kidded my executive officer about it after it was all over and we went back there a day or two later just out of curiosity and there's all the china and everything on the table.

I said something to my executive officer about the English sure knew how to occupy a country and he said well after all Colonel they've been occupying countries for 300 years they ought to learn something.
So that's the difference in American forces and the English forces.
We were transferred, we got cut off in the bulls from the American army and we were transferred for command purposes to the Second British Army under General Montgomery.
The next day, General Montgomery came down there.
He sent us a letter welcoming us.
I guess there were a half dozen units doing this.
But the next day, the old man came down and shook my hand and said, glad to have you in his army.
You bet.
What did you think of him?
Well, he was a tremendous personality.
That's all I know about him.
We were in his outfit for maybe a week or something like this before we were referred back to the 9th Army.
He came down and welcomed us.
So there's a different aspect of the English officer.
That was just a good public relation deal on his part.
It was good soldiering on his part.
And we, my battalion, and I'm sure my superiors appreciated it, because I couldn't help but report it to them.
Did the Americans do that on your guys?
I mean, did an American general come when you were assigned to a new area?
Did they come in and welcome you to their... No, basically you reported to them.
I see.
And I always went and reported to them.
Sometimes generals would welcome me and sometimes he'd be busy as hell.
I'd see him, I'd see his exec or the operation officer or somebody and let them know we were there and ready to go.
He'd say, well, we're glad to have you and we need you or something and that's it.
What did your men think of Montgomery coming down?
A big pardon?
What did your men think?
Oh, they were thrilled about it.
They appreciated it.
They rarely saw a senior officer.
If they saw a general once a month, he was just driving by.
But they never came and made a talk to him.
And General Montgomery made a talk to my headquarters battery.
And of course, he was talking to the whole battalion.
But my headquarters barrier was right around my headquarters, and I could get up 50, 60 people without any trouble, you know.
And he just came down and said, hello, welcome, and we're glad to have you, and anything you need, well, let me know about it, and I'll get it for you.
And that's it.
And do they do that?
Do they get you supplies?
Well, yeah, they furnish the supplies, meaning gasoline and food and
That kind of stuff.
Was there a difference between the food that they supplied versus the food that the 9th Army?
Oh, it was American food.
It was all American C rations or K rations.
I don't mean K or D rations.
Basically, it was all American food.
We were supplying them.
Sure.
Lend-lease.
Lend-lease.
Give them the food.
That's so much of my experience with General Montgomery.
And by the same token, I'll tell you a story of General Eisenhower.
When we were back in the Hocken area, Hocken was the center of Charlemagne's domain.
That was his capital during his reign, and he had a summer palace maybe 25 miles southeast of there at Cornelie Munster.
It was his summer palace and beautiful place, square block with a cloister all the way around it.
It was a beautiful place, castle type of thing.
I had to go down and see the Army artillery officer.
We were in the 9th Army at that time.
About something, I don't remember what it was.
I got down to Cornelia Munster, oh I got within a half mile of it.
And the MP stopped me and says,
You can't go any further.
And of course, I asked him, why not?
What the hell's happening here?
I got business down at the Army headquarters with an Army artillery officer.
He says, well, sir, if you've got business down there, of course, he checked my password and counter password and all this kind of business.
And he was able to verify that I was current as far as security was concerned.
He said, well, if you've got to go down there, you'll have to walk, because my orders are no
vehicles past this point.
And I'm sorry, but that's my orders.
And about that time, the MP sergeant came up and asked what the trouble was.
And I said, I just want to drive down.
I've got to go to the Army artillery officer's office.
And frankly, I don't know where it is.
I've never been there.
He said, well, Colonel, you can go down there, but you have to walk, because no vehicle is going past this stop point.
And of course, all I could do is say, well, that's your orders.
Thank you very much, Sergeant.
And how'd I get there?
And he showed me the roads to take and you could see the castle over here.
He showed me and he said, now you go down to the far southeast corner and that's the gate to use and you get in on it.
And I'm sure I was stopped a dozen times walking by different sentinels.
All of them checking the password and the counter password and my business and who I was and my identity and all.
And that was all right.
In retrospect, I admired it, but then it was a chore and a pain in the neck because it was hindering me, and I was busy, and I had something else to do.
So I'd mess with those people, but anyway, I got there.
I started down the hall, and this group of gentlemen came out of a conference room or a big room, and General Eisenhower, General Montgomery, some French general, all American men,
four-star and three-star generals.
I'd never seen so many general officers in my life.
General Patton was there, General Bradley was there, General Simpson was there, General Hodges was there.
Of course, I recognized them.
And as I approached them, they were walking toward me and General Montgomery and General Smith.
It was Peter Smith, his number one aide, helper.

and gentlemen were leading the pack coming up and of course I just approached them and kept going until I got within 10 or 15 feet of them and I backed up against the wall and took my helmet off and said good morning gentlemen and General Eisenhower wheeled out of the two and came over and said good morning and I reported my name to him and what my battalion number is
And he said, I've heard good things about that kid.
Well, that's a fine battalion.
You keep up the good work, boy, and he had been stomached like that, and that's all there was to it.
Really?
Yeah, that's right.
And like I say, I never saw the number, the jillions of generals.
A brigadier general was just like peons at this conference.
What it was all about, I don't know to this day.
I didn't try to inquire about it because none of my business.
But that was the reason for all this security.
I've often thought what a lucrative target that would have been to some German airplane going by and just decided, well, I'll unload my bombs and let them have it.
Because the whole safe headquarters and brains was there.
But that's two stories about General Eisenhower in Montgomery.
Well, what did you think about Eisenhower when he did that?
Well, it blew me up ten foot tall, and my damn shoulders went back, and my stomach pulled in, and it was the thrill of my life.
I bet.
It was the thrill of my life, and I couldn't help but tell the artillery officer about it, and he just lay and said, well, that's Ike or something.
You know, he just passed it off.
Was that Eisenhower was known for that?
Well...
He was known as being a soldier's soldier.
He'd stop and talk to soldiers.
And of course, he could see I was in combat, and probably dirty and muddy and filthy and all.
I was adamant about two things, about my people being clean shaven, and as long as I could brush my teeth, well, I was in good shape.
I could be dirty, and my clothes filthy, and my boots muddy and all, and I didn't pay attention to it.
all day's work, but I was clean shaven, had a decent haircut.
I certainly had a soldier's haircut.
How was Eisenhower's luck?
Great, great.
He was energetic, enthusiastic, and I'll never forget him hitting me in the stomach like that.
Keep up the good work, boy.
And, of course, I couldn't help but tell that to my driver going back, and
and the damn driver told all the battering and all the battalion and the story got out, I guess, holy to you.
But that was my experience with Jim Ladner.
I admired him tremendously.
It didn't take him 15 seconds to do it.
But it indelibly impressed on me that he was a great person.
I thought for one.
Very thoughtful, very thoughtful.
He was down here on a momentous mission and he made some decisions and he said you do this, I'm sure.
What he did was lay down the battle order and we would get a follow-up.
Or he wouldn't have had all of his field generals in, I mean the four-star generals, the army generals, and he, I guess all the way down to division.
I was
Oh, was he in fatigues or was he in dress?
Oh, no, no, no.
He was in his ODs with his jacket and all.
And all of them were.
It was a dress performance for them.
I never saw him in fatigues.
I never saw him but one time.
But he was a great person in my opinion.
In retrospect, I can understand of all the security.
Sure.
Absolutely.
Like you said, one mile an hour.
Paying the next start with, but I can understand it.
Anyway, I got out of there and did my business, got what information I needed or got whatever I went after.
Probably needed some help on some ammunition or something like that, you know, and I couldn't get through normal channels.
You go visit those people, you can shake them loose because they're always sitting on some extra.
It's a question of tapping the right source.
You learn to be pretty self-enterprising as a separate unit commander because you've got to go get everything you want.
It's not automatic coming down to you every day.
And if you're not enterprising, you just get left.
I was wondering a little bit about your schedule out in the field during combat.
Was there anything, of course your men have to have some time off.
They certainly get tired.
They get tired of combat too.
They must have to have some liberty sometime or have a few beers or drinks or something just to encourage them if there's something besides combat.
How did that work?
Well, yes and no.
You don't operate in combat by watch.
Oh, for sure.
Timing.
Absolutely.
Basically, you've got your three meals a day.
Breakfast is sun up and lunch in the middle of the day and your evening meal.
And you operate around those three fixed points of time.
Now, if you're in the middle of a fire mission and come dinner time, your dinner waits.
If it's an extended mission, why don't you infiltrate?
one or two men out of your section of time goes back and gets his food and comes back and eats it right there between fire missions.
Men understand that, don't they?
They understand it and they cooperate and coordinate and live with it.
You don't have any grousing about time off or working 40 hours a week or anything like that.
They work seven days a day around the clock.
Then again, when...
Your mission's over, and you can see a lull in the thing.
You completely relax, and if they want to go to get their meals, fine.
If they don't, fine.
You say relax and have a beer or drink.
The answer to that is, there's no way that we furnish them with that.
The American soldiers in Pride and Soul in the little towns, if there was any beer around, he found it.
He requisitioned it, if that's a good word.
If in a house, a blown-out house or something, he'd get in there and find a bottle of schnapps where they'd take it back to the section and drink it.
And it was a very informal thing, but when time came to move, you could interrupt him in anything, and he understood it was time to move, and he moved.
meaning one of the finest things that my battalion ever did, and we did that back in France, went through a farmhouse and they found a upright piano.
And one of my wire section boys could play a piano.
So they requisitioned this piano and put it in a wire truck up against the,
the cab, covered it up with wire so I wouldn't know anything about it.
And after so long time, every time we'd set up shop somewhere, got all the wire in and time to do it, there was something where this soldier would start playing piano.
And I'd happen by there and I'd see the same damn piano and find out, I'd ask the wire chief what goes here.
And he'd say, oh, we requisitioned that back in some old town of France.
And that was a great source of relaxation for that wire section.
They kept at the end all the way in Germany.
Frankly, I don't know what happened to it.
But they asked me if we could keep it.
And I said, sure, just as long as it doesn't become a burden to you in your wire section.
You've got to haul so many miles of wire.
And as long as you've got that wire there and you can transport it, that's fine.
And so this piano was a great source of relaxation for my whole headwaters, because they'd all wander in and they'd hear the music, you know, and they'd wander in and time off.
It was a great thing.
It was a great thing.
Did you ever give anyone leave to go back to Paris or anything like that?
No.
How did that work?
Yes and no.
The Army very quickly, after VE Day, set up rest centers.
They didn't do it, to my knowledge.
Well, they did, too.
They did, too.
Still in combat, they had some rest centers down in the French Riviera.
They were in Cannes and Nice.
And it went over nearly somewhere on the Italian Adriatic Sea.
And every now and then, I guess the Army and the Division got quarters.
And there again, they weren't any quarters for separate troops.
We didn't get any quarters.
And until after VE Day, then we got quarters.
The portals were all used up by the time they got to us.
That's the only excuse they had.
They were all given that.
And so I followed up on that thing.
And for a share, I was telling them to shake it up.
There were too few in the portal.
But once VGD happened, well, we got quarters.
And we'd get into people who had gotten hurt first.
And then the ones that had the most combat had to work it on down to the latest man.
Did you ever go to one of these restaurants?
I'm sorry?
Did you ever go to one of these restaurants?
Yeah, I went back to England.
I got to fly back to England one time.
Between transfers, and I think it was between transfers from the 777 battalion to the 745 battalion.
That's where I remember it.
When I got the telephone, oh, I think it was transferring from the 777 to the 745.
Which one?
How much time did it give you?
Well, I had five or six nights.
There again, the light, I pulled the switch and the light turned on for me.
I didn't have any relaxation or anything else.
The whole time, I just transferred to 745 Battalion.
